oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beyond the Buttocks as a Political-Geographical Model — A Praxeological Approach to West Germany’s National Revolutionaries
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sepp, Benedikt
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: National revolutionaries
West Germany
New Left
New Right
20th Century
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: At about the same time at which the West German anti-authoritarian student movement started to thrive in the middle of the sixties, a small group of young activists from the extreme right tried to combine “left” habitual elements with the aspiration to develop a sophisticated and genuinely “right” political theory, eventually leading to a new, young, progressive stance beyond allegedly out-dated categorisations like “left” and “right.” The article examines these self-proclaimed “national revolutionaries” from a praxeological point of view, arguing that the political extremes are constituted rather habitually than ideologically.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Moving the Social; Vol. 56 (2016): Essays on Social History and the History of Social Movements; 73-92
